It is said that the first four kinds are established based on three views.
It is said that a certain type of person
Gives rise to such views and establishes such doctrines, saying:
The life-principle is the same as the body.
Furthermore, there is a certain type of person
Who gives rise to such views and establishes such doctrines, saying:
The life-principle is different from the body.
Furthermore, there is a certain type of person
Who gives rise to such views and establishes such doctrines, saying:
This is my total self,
Pervading without duality, without difference, without deficiency.
Based on the first view, the first doctrine of having form and having perception after death is established.
It is said that this non-Buddhist school grasps form as the self.
They grasp the other four aggregates as what belongs to the self.
The self they grasp has the nature of form,
Therefore it is called having form.
Grasping the characteristics of phenomena is called perception.
Because this has form and I have that notion, it is called having a notion.
Because it grasps the four aggregates as its own,
it thinks like this.
This has form and I will have a notion after death.
This is in the desire realm and part of the form realm.
Except for the heaven of non-perception.
Those who allow that the formless realm also has form,
this is also in the first three formless realms.
Because this has a notion, it is not in the last one.
Based on the second view, the second theory of having a notion after death in the formless realm is established.
That non-Buddhist doctrine grasps the formless as the self.
It grasps form or the other four aggregates as its own.
It is said that if one excludes the notion and grasps the other three aggregates as the self, either collectively or individually,
then it grasps the notion and form aggregates as its own.
If one grasps the notion aggregate as the self,
then one grasps the other aggregates as one's own.
The self grasped by them has the nature of being formless, so it is called formless.
Grasping the characteristics of phenomena is called having a notion.
This formless self is either characterized by thought,
or it is said to have thought because it has the function of thinking,
or it is said to have thought because it has that thought.
Because it grasps the aggregate of thought as its own.
They think like this:
This formless self has thought after death.
This is in the desire realm up to the sphere of nothingness,
excluding the heaven of non-perception.
Based on the third view, the third self is established.
There is a theory that after death one has thought and is both with form and formless.
That is, those non-Buddhists grasp form and the formless as the self.
Like the non-Buddhist Ä€jÄ«vikas and others.
They generally give rise to the thought of self with regard to the five aggregates.
Because they each separately discriminate the aggregates and do not attain the true self,
just as one separately discriminates sweetness, sourness, saltiness, bitterness, and blandness.
There is no generally real single taste that can be attained.
They give rise to a single thought with regard to the aggregates and generally grasp it as the self.
The self grasped by them is characterized by form and the formless.
Therefore, it is also called having form and also formless.
Grasping the characteristics of dharmas is called conceptualization.
This is also the self that has form and is formless.
Or it is said to have conceptualization as its nature.ğŸ”½Or it has the function of conceptualization and is called having conceptualization.
Or it has that conceptualization and is called having conceptualization.ğŸ”½Because it grasps the aggregates of one's own body as the self.
Because it grasps the aggregates of others as what belongs to the self.
There are other non-Buddhists.
Having seen the faults in the view of a self with form,
they abide in a formless self.
Having seen the faults in the view of a formless self,
they again abide in a self with form.
Those non-Buddhists have not yet eliminated the view of a self.
Although they grasp at a self, it is not definite.
They say that the grasped self is only with form or only formless.
However, they think like this.
This is also with form and also formless.
After my death, I have conceptualization. This is in the desire realm, completely according to what is appropriate.
And so on, explaining in detail.
The fourth is the theory that after death, the self has neither form nor no form and has perception.
This refutes the third view of no basis.
They think like this:
Although the self really exists, it cannot be said to definitely have form or no form.
They see that the real self definitely has form and no form.
Both have faults, so they say:
This self has neither form nor no form after death and has perception.
The rest is as explained above.
These four kinds all arise based on investigation and discernment, or based on meditative absorption.
Those who hold the theory that after death, the self has boundaries and has perception,
if they grasp form as the self,
then the self they grasp has a limited substance.
Either it is in the mind, the size of a finger joint, with blazing light,
or it is in the body, the size of the body, with light inside and outside.
As it is said, the self and its form are upright, with blazing light, pure and supreme.
The Venerable Gautama would rather say there is no self.
If one grasps what is not form as the self,
the self that is grasped also has limitations.
Because the form-free dharmas have a limited basis and objects.
It is also called having boundaries.
That [view] arises based on applied thought and sustained thought.
If this view arises based on meditative absorption, one has definitely not yet attained the base of infinite space.
These two kinds [of views] both think like this:
I definitely have boundaries. After death, there will be conceptual thoughts.
This [view] is in the desire realm and the entire form realm,
except for the heaven of non-perceptual beings.
For those who allow that the formless realm also has form, this [view] is also in the first three formless [realms].
As for those who hold the view that after death there will be conceptual thoughts if the self is boundless,
if one grasps form as the self,
the self that is grasped is all-pervading.
As the Bright Scriptures say:
There is a self and a person whose extent is vast and whose boundaries are difficult to measure.
Their radiance and color are like the sun.
Even though the blind dwell in front of them, they cannot see [the self].
One must know this self in order to be able to transcend birth, old age, sickness, and death.
Apart from this, there is no other principle for transcendence.
Moreover, there is a saying:
Earth is precisely my self, and my self is precisely earth.
Its extent is boundless.
If one grasps the formless as the self,
one thinks like this:
Just as one can never be burned if one does not approach fire,
one can never be cut if one does not approach a knife,
and one can never be moistened if one does not approach water,
in the same way, if there is anything that does not approach the self, it can never grasp the boundless extent.
They give rise to this grasping based on investigation and analysis.
If one gives rise to this grasping based on meditative absorption, one must have already attained the base of infinite space.
These two kinds of people both think like this:
After death, I will definitely have a perception of the boundless.
This is entirely according to what is appropriate in the desire realm.
And so on, explaining in detail.
As for those who hold the view that after death there is a perception of having a self that is both limited and boundless,
if one grasps form as the self,
The self that they grasp, following the body that it relies on,
either contracts or expands, its extent being indefinite.
They think like this:
If the body has a measure, then the self is limited.
If the body is immeasurable, then the self is unlimited.
If one grasps the formless as the self,
they think like this:
If it follows the measured basis of reliance and objects, then the self is limited.
If it follows the immeasurable basis of reliance and objects, then the self is unlimited.
In this way, these two kinds of people think like this:
After death, the self is both limited and unlimited, and there is conceptualization.
This is in the desire realm, completely according to what is appropriate.
And so on, explaining in detail.
Those who hold the view that after death there is conceptualization and the self is neither limited nor unlimited,
immediately deny the third and make this the fourth.
The three gates of different explanations should be understood as before.
In this way, these four kinds, either relying on investigation and analysis or relying on meditative absorption,
are all able to arise.
Based on the differences in conceptualization and feeling, it is said like this.
I have one kind of perception, I have various kinds of perception, I have a small perception, I have an immeasurable perception.
I am purely happy, I am purely suffering.
After death I will have perception, I will have neither suffering nor happiness.
Here, one who has one kind of perception refers to those in the first three formless realms.
Because their perceptions arise through one door, they are said to have one kind of perception.
One who has various kinds of perception refers to those in the desire and form realms.
Excluding the non-percipient devas.
Because their perceptions arise through six doors and four doors, and because they take various objects as their objects, they are called those who have various kinds of perception.
Those who rely on applied thought and sustained thought also have distinctions.
That is to say, one who has one kind of skill in arts and crafts is called one who has one kind of perception.
If one has various kinds of skill in arts and crafts, one is called one who has various kinds of perception.
One who has a small perception refers toğŸ”½grasping a small amount of form as the self,
or grasping a small amount of the formless as the self.
If one grasps a small amount of form as the self,
Their attachment to form as the self is limited and small,
like the size of a finger joint and so on.
They attach to thought as the self.
Because the body that supports it is small and because it takes few objects as its objects,
it is said to be small thought.
The self is united with that, and is called having small thought.
This exists in the entire desire realm and part of the form realm,
excluding the heaven of non-perceptual beings.
For those who allow that the formless realm also has form,
this also exists in the first three formless realms.
If one attaches to a small amount of formlessness as the self,
one may either attach to it as the thought of the self or as what belongs to the self.
Because it is based on a small body,
and because it takes few objects as its objects,
it is said to be small thought.
The self is united with that, and is called having small thought.
Attaching to activity as the self and attaching to consciousness as the self,
the extensive explanation is also like this.
If one attaches to thought as the self,
because that thought is based on a small body and takes few objects as its objects,
it is said to be small thought.
Because they attach to small thought as the nature of the self,
or because there is the function of thought, it is called having small thought.
This [view] exists in the desire realm up to the sphere of nothingness.
Excluding the heaven of non-perceptual beings.
As for I have immeasurable perceptions,
it means grasping immeasurable form as the self or grasping immeasurable formlessness as the self.
If one grasps immeasurable form as the self,
one grasps form as the self pervading everywhere.
That one grasps perception as the self,
because the basis is immeasurable bodies and because it takes immeasurable objects as its objects, it is called having immeasurable perceptions.
The self is united with that, so it is called having immeasurable perceptions.
This [view] exists in the desire realm in its entirety and in part of the form realm.
Excluding the heaven of non-perceptual beings.
For those who allow that the formless realm also has form,
this [view] also exists in the first three formless realms.
If one grasps immeasurable formlessness as the self,
one either grasps it as the self or as what belongs to the self.
Because that perception is based on immeasurable bodies and because it takes immeasurable objects as its objects, it is called having immeasurable perceptions.
The self is united with that, so it is called having immeasurable perceptions.
Grasping volitional activity as the self or grasping consciousness as the self,
The extensive explanation is also like this.
If one grasps thought as the self,
because that thought relies on innumerable bodies and takes innumerable objects as its objects, it is called having innumerable thoughts.
Because they grasp innumerable thoughts as the nature of the self,
or because they have the function of thought, they are called having innumerable thoughts.
This exists in the desire realm up to the sphere of nothingness.
Excluding the heaven of non-perception.
In this way, these four kinds may arise relying on investigation and analysis, or may arise relying on meditative absorption.
Those who say they have only pleasure
refer to those in the first three meditative absorptions.
Those who attain meditative absorption see with the supernormal power of the divine eye that beings in the three meditative absorptions always experience pleasure.
Later, after passing away from there, they are reborn in this world.
They then think, I have only pleasure.
Those who investigate and analyze see that all beings at all times are in union with pleasure.
They then think, I have only pleasure.
In this world and in other worlds, it is also like this.
Those who say they have only suffering
refer to those in the hells.
Those who attain concentration see with the supernormal power of the divine eye that beings in hell are always experiencing suffering.
Later, after passing away from there, they are reborn in this world.
They then think, I have only suffering.
Those who engage in discursive thought see that all beings are always in conjunction with suffering.
They then think, I have only suffering.
It is the same in this world and in other worlds.
As for I have suffering and happiness,
it refers to animals, ghosts, humans, and the gods of the desire realm.
Those who attain concentration see with the supernormal power of the divine eye that those beings experience a mixture of suffering and happiness.
Later, after passing away from there, they are reborn in this world.
They then think, I have suffering and happiness.
Those who engage in discursive thought see that beings sometimes experience conjunction with suffering and sometimes experience conjunction with happiness.
They then think, I have suffering and happiness.
It is the same in this world and in other worlds.
As for I have neither suffering nor happiness,
That is, from the fourth meditation up to the sphere of nothingness.
Those who attain concentration know that those beings are without suffering and without pleasure.
Later, after death, they are reborn in this world.
They then think, I am without suffering and without pleasure.
Those who engage in discursive thought have this thought.
My essence is permanent, but it evolves unclearly.
Although there is a temporary association with suffering and pleasure, they are guests and I do not have them.
These sixteen kinds of distinctions about the later limit.
All theories about having conceptualization arise based on the aforementioned sixteen things.
As for the eight theories about being without conceptualization,
they are the four about having form, etc., and the four about having boundaries, etc.
As for the four about having form, etc.,
the first is the view that after death, one who has form is without conceptualization.
That is, they grasp form as the self and attain the concentration of non-conceptualization.
And seeing others attain that concentration and be born in the heaven of beings with non-conceptualization, they think like this.
I, who have form, will be without conceptualization after death.
I will be born in the heaven of beings with non-conceptualization, because conceptualization does not arise.
Those who speculate and ponder grasp form as the self.
Seeing that in wind sickness, deep sleep, fainting, and intense pain, there seems to be no thought at all, they think:
Although I have form, I have no thought.
This is the same in this world and in other worlds.
The second is the view that the self is formless and has no thought after death.
That is, they grasp the faculty of life as the self and attain the attainment of non-perception.
And seeing others attain that concentration and be born in the heaven of non-percipient beings,
they think:
I will be formless and have no thought after death, and will be born in the heaven of non-percipient beings.
Because thought does not arise.
Those who speculate and ponder grasp the faculty of life as the self.
Seeing that in wind sickness, deep sleep, fainting, and intense pain, there seems to be no thought at all,
they think:
I am formless and also have no thought.
This is the same in this world and in other worlds.
Those who speculate and ponder, except for grasping thought, grasp the other three aggregates as the self.
They may also grasp the view that the self is formless and has no thought after death.
The third is the view that after death the self exists both with form and without form and is without thought.
This means that they grasp form and the faculty of life as the self.
They give rise to the notion of a single self with regard to these two.
Because they separately discriminate these two and do not attain the true self,
just as one does not attain the general taste by separately discriminating sweetness, etc.
They grasp these two as a single self, attain the concentration of non-perception,
and see others attain that concentration and be born in the heaven of non-percipient beings.
They then think,
After death, I will also exist both with form and without form and be without thought.
I will be born in the heaven of non-percipient beings.
Because thought does not arise.
Those who speculate grasp form and the faculty of life as the self.
They see that when struck by wind, epilepsy, deep sleep, fainting, or painful feelings, they seem completely without thought.
They then think,
I also exist both with form and without form, but am completely without thought.
In this world and in other worlds, it is the same.

Those who have applied thought and sustained thought may also grasp the four aggregates other than conceptualization as the self. They may also grasp the self as both having form and formless, and as having no conceptualization after death.
The fourth is the view that the self is neither form nor formless, and has no conceptualization after death.
This fourth view is established by negating the third view.
The three gates and different explanations should be understood as before.
The four views of having a limit, etc.
The first is the view that the self has a limit and has no conceptualization after death.
This means that if one grasps form as the self,
one grasps form as the self, and its extent is narrow and small,
like the joints of the fingers, etc.
If one grasps the formless as the self,
one grasps the faculty of life as the self.
It pervades the body and conforms to the size of the body's form.
Having thus grasped, one attains the concentration of non-conceptualization.
And seeing others attain that concentration and be born in the heaven of non-conceptual sentient beings,
one thinks like this:
My self has a limit and has no conceptualization after death.
I will be born in the heaven of non-conceptual sentient beings.
Because conceptualization does not arise.
Those who speculate and ponder also grasp it as the self. There is a kind of insanity.
According to their respective cases,
as explained in detail above.
Second, grasping the self as boundless, thinking there is no thought after death.
That is to say, if one grasps form as the self,
they grasp form as the self that pervades everywhere.
If one grasps the formless as the self,
they grasp the life faculty as the self.
It also pervades everywhere.
Having grasped in this way, one attains the concentration of non-perception,
and sees others attain that concentration and be born in the heaven of non-percipient sentient beings.
One then thinks,
My boundless self has no thought after death.
It will be born in the heaven of non-percipient sentient beings.
Because thought does not arise.
Those who speculate and ponder also grasp it as the self.
They see a kind of insanity.
As explained in detail above, according to their respective cases.
Third, grasping the self as both bounded and boundless, thinking there is no thought after death.
That is to say, if one grasps form as the self,
they grasp form as the self that either contracts or expands.
If one grasps formlessness as the self,
one grasps the life faculty as the self.
Just as the body and form may be rolled up or extended,
having thus grasped, one attains the concentration of non-perception,
and sees others attaining that concentration and being born in the heaven of non-percipient beings,
one then thinks,
After death, I will be neither with perception nor without perception,
and will be born in the heaven of non-percipient beings.
Because perception does not arise.
Those who engage in discursive thought also grasp that as the self,
as explained in detail above as appropriate.
Fourth, grasping after death, I will be neither with a limit nor without a limit and without perception,
is a negation of the third and becomes the fourth.
The three gates and different explanations should be understood as before.
These eight kinds of distinctions about the later limit,
the theories of non-perception are based on the above-mentioned eight kinds of events.
As for the eight theories of neither perception nor non-perception,ğŸ”½they are the four of having form, etc., and the four of having a limit, etc.
As for the four of having form, etc.,
First, some hold that after death, the self has neither perception nor non-perception.
This refers to those who seek and investigate, who take form as the self.
They see that the perceptions of sentient beings are unclear.
They then think,
I have form, but neither perception nor non-perception.
This is so in this world and in other worlds.
One who has not attained that concentration cannot have this view.
Why is this?
One who has already become detached from the defilements of the sphere of nothingness,
can only take the aggregates of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as the self.
Since they have no form, this view has no basis. It is explained with a different meaning.
Even those who have attained that concentration can have this view.
This refers to those who have been born in the desire or form realms and have already become detached from the defilements of the sphere of nothingness,
who take the aggregates of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as the self.
The substance of the self they grasp is not form,
but it is called a self with form because it is combined with form.
It is like saying there is a person with a topknot, but the substance of the person is not the topknot.
Although they do not take form as their self-possession,
But the self they grasp is not yet free from the body.
Until the end of life it still follows the body, and therefore they say the self has form.
Because of the unclear thought in the concentration of neither conceptualization nor non-conceptualization they enter,
they grasp the self as presently neither conceptualizing nor non-conceptualizing, and after death it will be the same.
Those who admit that the formless realm also has form,
admit that there is grasping of the self in the sphere of neither conceptualization nor non-conceptualization as really having form.
But it is neither conceptualizing nor non-conceptualizing.
The second is the grasping of the self as formless after death, neither conceptualizing nor non-conceptualizing.
This refers to those who attain that concentration grasping the formless aggregates in the sphere of neither conceptualization nor non-conceptualization as the self.
Or as belonging to the self.
The self they grasp has the nature of being formless.
Or because it is either formless or has no form, it is called a formless self.
Because of the unclear thought in the concentration of neither conceptualization nor non-conceptualization they enter,
they grasp the self as presently neither conceptualizing nor non-conceptualizing, and after death it will be the same.
Those who contemplate and discern take the formless as the self.
They see that the thoughts of sentient beings are unclear and have this thought:
I am neither form nor formless, neither with thought nor without thought.
In this world and in other worlds, it is the same.
The third is the view that after death, the self is both with form and formless, neither with thought nor without thought.
This refers to those who contemplate and discern who take form and the formless as the self.
They see that the thoughts of sentient beings are unclear.
They then have this thought:
I am both with form and formless, neither with thought nor without thought.
In this world and in other worlds, it is the same.
One who has not attained that concentration may have this view.
Why is it so?
One who has already become free from the defilements of the sphere of nothingness
can take the aggregates of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as the self.
Since they have no form, this view is unreasonable.
It is explained based on a different meaning.
Even those who have attained that concentration may have this view.
It refers to those who have been born in the desire or form realms and have already become detached from the contamination of the sphere of nothingness.
They grasp the aggregates of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as the self.
The substance of the self grasped by them is not form, but it is called a self with form because it is combined with form.
It is like saying there is a person with a topknot, while the substance of the person is not the topknot. Although they do not grasp form as the self,
the self grasped by them is not yet free from the form body.
Because it still follows the body until the end of life, it is said that the self also has form.
Because they grasp the formless as the self, it is said that the self is also formless.
Because the conception of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception entered by them is not clear,
they grasp the self as neither having perception nor not having perception in the present, and the same after death.
Those who admit that the formless realm also has form,
admit that there is the grasping of the self of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, which is also real, having both form and the formless,
but neither having perception nor not having perception.
The fourth grasps the self as neither having form nor being formless,
and as neither having perception nor not having perception after death.
This is the fourth view, which is different from the third.
The three gates of views should be understood as explained above.
The four views of having an end, etc. are as follows:
First, one holds that after death, one's self has an end and is neither with nor without thought.
Second, one holds that after death, one's self is boundless and is neither with nor without thought.
Third, one holds that after death, one's self is both finite and infinite and is neither with nor without thought.
Fourth, one holds that after death, one's self is neither finite nor infinite and is neither with nor without thought.
All of these views hold the formless as the self.
Those who have attained the concentration of neither perception nor non-perception may all have these views.
Moreover, all of these may hold the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.
The four formless aggregates as the self and what belongs to the self.
First, because the duration of that concentration is short,
taking each aggregate as the object, one holds that one's self has an end.
Second, because the duration of that concentration is long,
Because they take the four aggregates as their object, they grasp the self as boundless.
Third, because the duration of their concentration is either short or long.
Either taking each aggregate or the four aggregates as a whole as their object,
they grasp the self as both bounded and unbounded.
This refutes the third and makes it the fourth.
The three different explanations should be understood as before.
Here, all of them are due to the unclear understanding of the thought of entering the concentration of neither perception nor non-perception.
They grasp the self as neither having perception nor not having perception in the present, and the same after death.
Those who engage in discursive thought and those who accept that the formless realm also has form,
grasp form and the formless as the self.
As appropriate, this is explained in detail as before.
These eight kinds of speculation about the future, the theory of neither perception nor non-perception,
arise based on the previously mentioned eight things.

Question: Why are the theories of neither perception nor non-perception and neither having perception nor not having perception not explained in terms of the self having one perception, etc., and the eight?
Answer: If one also speaks of this, then all should be called theories of existence.
Because those who have thoughts and feelings are not without thoughts and so on.
In this way, all theories of existence and so on say that after death,
they are all included in the views of discrimination about the future.
As for the seven theories of annihilation,
one thinks like this:
This self has a coarse nature that is created from the four great elements.
After death, it is completely annihilated and never exists again.
This is called the correct annihilation of the self.
They see that when one is born, entering the womb is the beginning and death is the end. Then they think like this:
When I entered the womb, I originally did not exist but now exist.
If I reach the state of death, having existed I will return to non-existence. This is called good annihilation.
Second, one thinks like this:
This self of the desire realm gods is annihilated after death and never exists again.
This is called the correct annihilation of the self.
They think like this:
Since I was not born through the birth canal,ğŸ”½I originally did not exist but now exist.
Having existed, I will return to non-existence.
It is like a comet, etc., which is called good annihilation.
Third, he thinks:
After the death of this self in the form realm, it is annihilated and ultimately non-existent.
This is called my correct annihilation.
He thinks:
Since I was not born through the birth canal,
I originally did not exist but now do.
Due to the power of meditative absorption,
having existed, I will again become non-existent. This is called good annihilation.
Some say:
These three views of annihilation all arise in relation to sentient beings who have already become detached from the first meditative absorption.
As for those with the view of annihilation,
although they have already attained meditative absorption, they are still unable to become detached from the defilements of the first meditative absorption.
The divine eye they have developed only sees the lower realms.
The three sentient beings mentioned above, after their lives end, are all reborn in the upper realms.
The intermediate existence, the existence at birth, and so forth that they undergo,
are not within the scope of their perception. They then think:
Those who attain meditative absorption are all completely annihilated after their lives end.
Fourth, he thinks:
This self of mine, after death, will be annihilated and will cease to exist.
This is called the correct annihilation of self.
Fifth, one thinks:
This self of mine, after death, will be annihilated and will cease to exist.
This is called the correct annihilation of self.
Sixth, one thinks:
This self of mine, after death, will be annihilated and will cease to exist.
This is called the correct annihilation of self.
Seventh, one thinks:
This self of mine, after death, will be annihilated and will cease to exist.
This is called the correct annihilation of self.
Among these, the last four hold the view that the sphere of infinite space is the summit of existence,
up to holding the view that the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is the summit of existence.
If one holds the view that the sphere of infinite space is the summit of existence,

Why do non-Buddhists hold that the life-principle is the same as the body?
Venerable Vasumitra says:
They see that in the world, when the body is born, it is said that sentient beings are born.
Because when the body perishes, it is said that sentient beings die.
Moreover, they see that in the world, with regard to a body with material faculties, it is said that there is a living being,
and with regard to a body without material faculties, it is said that there is no living being.
Moreover, they see that in the world, with regard to the differences in bodily characteristics, the notions of male and female are produced.
Moreover, they see that in the world, with regard to the strength or weakness of the body, the strong and the weak are spoken of.

Moreover, they see that in the world, with regard to the differences in the body's height, shortness, coarseness, fineness, corpulence, thinness, whiteness, and blackness, the tall, the short, and so forth are spoken of.
Moreover, they see that in the world, when one part of the body is injured,
the entire body experiences the suffering of discomfort.
Moreover, they see that in the world, when there is sorrow or joy,
tears flow, the hair stands on end, and the countenance is cheerful.
Moreover, they see that in the world, with regard to the body, the notion of self and the notion of name are produced.
Other masters say:
They see that in the world, when the tail of a chameleon or a lizard is cut off,ğŸ”½it can still move.
Therefore, they think that the self is one and the body is many.
The Venerable One said:
They see that in the world, regarding the physical body with form and faculties, there is the appearance of sentient beings,
the speech of sentient beings,
the good and bad of sentient beings,
the deportment of sentient beings,
the activities of sentient beings, and so on.
For these various reasons,
the non-Buddhists say that the life-principle is the same as the body.
Why do the non-Buddhists hold the view that the life-principle is different from the body?
Venerable Vasumitra said:
Those non-Buddhists take form to be the body,
and take mind and mental factors to be the life-principle.
The continuity of form and mind, etc. is different.
They perceive the transformation of the physical body before and after,
but do not perceive the different aspects of mind, etc. before and after.
Therefore, they give rise to this view. Furthermore, they see that the body is coarse and the mind and mental factors are subtle.
Since the life-principle is subtle, it is different from the body.
Furthermore, they see that deportment changes according to one's wishes.
They take intention to be the life-principle.
Deportment is the transformation and distinction of the body.
Furthermore, they see that the body of the dead person is no different.
They then think:
The life principle, apart from the body, is called death, therefore it is different from the body.
Furthermore, they see that the physical body and the mind and mental factors change in different ways before and after.
They hold that the mind and so forth are the life principle, therefore it is different from the body.
Furthermore, they see that the physical body has many parts.
While the life principle is one, therefore it is different from the body.
Furthermore, those non-Buddhists see that one abandons the body of a previous existence and takes on the body of an intermediate existence.
Again, one abandons the body of the intermediate existence and takes on the body of the present existence.
In this way, although the body is different, the life principle is one, therefore it is different from the body.
Other masters say:
They see that when one is asleep, the body also moves and changes.
Therefore, they know that there is a separate life principle in the middle.
Furthermore, they see that when one is dreaming,

Therefore, they know that it is different from the body and there is a separate life principle.
There are also those who say:
They see that one can remember the past and know the future by relying on concentration.

Therefore they know that apart from the body, there is a life-principle.
Some say:

Some say:

Question: How should one know that after death it is not annihilated?
Venerable Vasumitra said:
One sees that at present the mind continues in many moments.
Due to the cessation of the previous, the subsequent arises.
The subsequent mind necessarily arises based on the previous mind.
The previous mind with power necessarily attracts the subsequent mind.
When encountering the extreme condition of disgust, it subsequently does not arise.
Therefore, the mind of the first birth in this world definitely has a previous mind as its cause.
At the time of death, there is an extreme aversion condition.
The mind at the moment of death definitely gives rise to the next [life].
Since the previous body can give rise to the present body,
why does the present body not give rise to the next body?
Therefore, you should know that after death, it is not cut off.
Furthermore, it is seen that the present root consciousness arises based on the previous root consciousness and can again serve as a cause to give rise to mental consciousness.
Therefore, it is known that the initial mental consciousness in the womb must be given rise to by the past root consciousness.
Since the previous life can give rise to the present life,
why does the present life not give rise to the next life?
Therefore, you should know that after death, it is not cut off.
The Venerable One said:
Apart from other minds, there are no other minds that arise.
It is also seen that form arises in accordance with the mind.
It is also seen that the mind arises based on form.
Because of afflictions, form and mind arise. Therefore, you should know that after death, it is not cut off.
Moreover, we directly perceive that a mind and form with afflictions in the previous moment are definitely able to give rise to mind and form in the subsequent moment.
We know that one who has afflictions at the time of death is definitely able to give rise to subsequent mind and form.
Therefore, we should know that after death, there is no annihilation.
Question: Why are mind, form, etc. not permanent?
Answer: They transform and are not constant.
How could they be permanent?
Question: How do we know that transformation is not due to concealment and manifestation, but rather that their substance has arising and ceasing?
Venerable Vasumitra said:
If transformation were only due to concealment and manifestation,
then the stages of being in the womb, infant, child, youth, middle-aged, and old would all arise suddenly.
However, they arise gradually.
Therefore, we know that transformation has arising and ceasing in its substance, and is not due to concealment and manifestation.
Moreover, if transformation were only due to concealment and manifestation,
then the stages of being in the womb, infant, child, youth, middle-aged, and old would be interrupted.
However, they are not interrupted.
Therefore, we know that transformation has arising and ceasing in its substance, and is not due to concealment and manifestation.
The Venerable One said:
In the world, when various conditions come together, phenomena arise.
If the conditions are disrupted, the phenomena are destroyed.
That which is not hidden or manifest does not have this distinction.
Therefore, we know that transformation is not due to concealment or manifestation.
It is only due to the arising and cessation of that substance itself.
Furthermore, when a dharma transforms, the differences between the previous and subsequent moments also must be different in substance.
Because the characteristics and substance are the same.
If a dharma is permanent, although there are distinctions in states of concealment and manifestation, the characteristics are not different.
